sn21.8:4.2: Then Venerable Nanda—the Buddha’s cousin on his mother’s side—dressed in nicely pressed and ironed robes, applied eyeshadow, and took a polished black bowl. He went to the Buddha,
sn21.8:4.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
sn21.8:4.5: “Nanda, as a son of a good family who has gone forth in faith from the lay life into homelessness, it’s not appropriate for you to dress in nicely pressed and ironed robes, apply eyeshadow, and carry a polished black bowl.
sn21.8:4.6: It’s appropriate for you to stay in the wilderness, eat only alms-food, wear rag robes, and live without concern for sensual pleasures.
sn21.8:4.7: This is what the Buddha said.
sn21.8:4.8: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn21.8:5.2: in the wilderness, wearing rag robes,
sn21.8:5.3: feeding on scraps offered by strangers,
sn21.8:6.1: Then some time later Venerable Nanda stayed in the wilderness, ate only alms-food, wore rag robes, and lived without concern for sensual pleasures.
